Body:
I am wondering if it is possible to install upm package for micropython

https://github.com/intel-iot-devkit/upm/tree/master/examples/python

and if so
column9:
if anyone has any idea how?

"

Body: From a quick look at the datasheet it won't be a trivial task to write your own driver for that sensor, at least if you need its full functionality. See my answer.

It looks to me as if the upm Python package is a Python binding for a [whole load of drivers written in C](https://github.com/intel-iot-devkit/upm) that in turn depend on something called [MRAA](https://iotdk.intel.com/docs/master/mraa/) that runs on Linux, so even if you could install the Python package I don't think that'll get you anywhere on any Micropython platform. What platform are you actually using and what devices do you want to talk to?

Thanks...this really isnt my area of expertise.. I want" to use a pyboard to interface with a LSM6DSL gyro/accelerometer. I was attempting to comprehend the datasheet to see if I could write my own i2c scripts in micropython but really don't know alot about deciphering which registers/values to write to control it the way I want. Luckily there is a UPM python script that does exactly this
column9: but I might have to resort to a RPi or something of the sort"

Body: No. The upm Python package appears to be a a Python binding for a collection of drivers written in C that in turn depend on something called MRAA that's written to run under Linux
column9:
so even if you could install the Python package I don't think that'll get you anywhere on any MicroPython platform.

If what you're actually interested in is a specific device
column10: such as the LSM6DSL inertial measurement unit
column11: you could look for an existing MicroPython driver for that
column12: or for help writing one yourself - I found a post about this sensor on the MicroPython forum
column13:
so you could try asking there.

Otherwise if you need to use upm I think you'll have to move to a Linux-based platform such as the Raspberry Pi.

"
